ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: This course should be very valuable to anyone going into forest or woody plant botanical sciences, but I didn't feel I got out of it as much as I would have liked. It seemed there would have been good opportunity to integrate lab or visual/field trip experience with the course, but it was not done. It was all lecture.

Question 1: The readings were not helpful because so many textbooks were assigned. It was too expensive and cumbersome to deal with so many textbooks, so I just bought one. It was somewhat helpful.Question 2: The class would have been much more helpful if Professor Berlyn would present and follow an outline for each lecture. Each lecture appeared to have no architecture to it: at nearly every point, I did not know what I was learning or how it was relevant to other things we had covered. In addition, Professor Berlyn puts up slides, reads or explains a part of the slide (often full of dense text) then whips it off the projector before we can understand how it relates, what it's key takeaway is, or write down what it says. I felt like I never knew what I was supposed to be learning at any given time.
Prof. Berlyn did a great job recognizing that students in this class had very different backgrounds and levels of experience and adjusted his expectations accordingly.
The subject material and the depth in which each subject was covered.
The amount of information was tremendous, covering a wide variety of topics as well as going into detail on a number of subjects.
The professor has a very deep knowledge base and does a great job contextualizing what in the field is known vs "known."
Professor Berlyn is a very nice man who has a wealth of knowledge on tree physiology. He provided interesting history of FES and the study of trees.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Maybe a bit more structure in the lectures
More lab work would be helpful.
It needs a TALab hours and exercises.

The course would be much better if it were somewhat more dynamic - either with a TA who could hold study sessions, with field trips (even on campus) or labs that tie in some of what is learned in class, more tie-in to current readings and studies, or more visuals.
Information architecture.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Sufficient
The instructor is always available to help his students.
Professor Berlyn was available after every class to discuss any questions, which was great. I don't know that there was officially a TA.
When I asked Professor Berlyn for help understanding what the key takeaways were from an early class, he said, "Oh, it's all important." That's the last time I asked for help.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I wanted a strong background in plant physiology which made this class perfect for my goals.
This course is not required but is important informational background for working with trees.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: It fit into my schedule, fulfilled a requirement, seemed interesting, and Prof. Berlyn is an authority in the field.
For the subject matter, and because of the professor teaching the course.
It matched my interests strongly
It is related to my research interests.
It seemed like important information to know for my career direction.
I needed the course to fulfill a bin.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes.
Very much so.
Absolutely
Not really

I was not very engaged in the class, and unfortunately I found it easy to disengage from the outside readings as well. Therefore, I didn't get out of it what I had hoped to as far as a working knowledge base of tree physiology.
It did not live up to my expectations.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes, and more.
Yes.
Yes
Mostly.
No.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It was very helpful to hear what others had picked up and how they had made sense of it.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take full advantage of the materials posted on the class website, and spend the lectures listening rather than taking detailed notes
If you do not have a strong foundation in plant science or in biology/biochemistry, you would do well to read the prescribed textbooks thoroughly.

The material of this course is important, but I wish there were a 1-credit option that would encourage me to do some of the readings and learn from Berlyn about some topics, but I didn't get what I would consider to be 3 credits worth of understanding out of the course based on the limited work I put in.
Get together with peers often to discuss the material, and make time to do some reading. Share books with classmates to reduce the number you feel compelled to buy.
